review.title: Semi-Proximal Mirror-Prox for Nonsmooth Composite Minimization
review.abstract: We propose a new first-order optimisation algorithm to solve high-dimensional non-smooth composite minimisation problems. Typical examples of such problems have an objective that decomposes into a non-smooth empirical risk part and a non-smooth regularisation penalty. The proposed algorithm, called Semi-Proximal Mirror-Prox, leverages the Fenchel-type representation of one part of the objective while handling the other part of the objective via linear minimization over the domain. The algorithm stands in contrast with more classical proximal gradient algorithms with smoothing, which require the computation of proximal operators at each iteration and can therefore be impractical for high-dimensional problems. We establish the theoretical convergence rate of Semi-Proximal Mirror-Prox, which exhibits the optimal complexity bounds, i.e. $O(1/\epsilon^2)$, for the number of calls to linear minimization oracle. We present promising experimental results showing the interest of the approach in comparison to competing methods.

sections.heading: 3 Semi-Proximal Mirror-Prox for Semi-structured Variational In-
sections.text: Semi-structured variation inequalities (Semi-VI) have a special product structure that allows to get the best out of two worlds, namely the proximal setup (where the proximal operator can be calculated) and the LMO setup (where the linear minimization oracle can be calculated). Basically, domain X as a cartesian product is split into two sets X = X1 × X2, so that X1 allows a proximal mapping, while X2 allows a linear minimization oracle. We will now describe the most important theoretical and algorithmic components of the semiproximal mirror prox algorithm, respectively in Sec. 3.1 and Sec. 3.2, and finally the overall algorithm in Sec. 3.3.

sections.heading: B Theoretical analysis of composite Mirror Prox with inexact
sections.text: The theoretical convergence rate noted in Theorem 3.1 and Corollary 3.1 extends the previous result in Corollary 3.1 in [12] for CMP with exact prox mappings. In fact, if exact prox mappings are used, we recover from the result [12]. If inexact prox mappings are used, the errors are accumulated due to the inaccuracy of the prox mappings and are reflected in the bound (34) and (14).Theorem 3.1.

metadata.abstractText: We propose a new first-order optimisation algorithm to solve high-dimensional non-smooth composite minimisation problems. Typical examples of such problems have an objective that decomposes into a non-smooth empirical risk part and a non-smooth regularisation penalty. The proposed algorithm, called Semi-Proximal Mirror-Prox, leverages the Fenchel-type representation of one part of the objective while handling the other part of the objective via linear minimization over the domain. The algorithm stands in contrast with more classical proximal gradient algorithms with smoothing, which require the computation of proximal operators at each iteration and can therefore be impractical for high-dimensional problems. We establish the theoretical convergence rate of Semi-Proximal Mirror-Prox, which exhibits the optimal complexity bounds, i.e. O(1/ ), for the number of calls to linear minimization oracle. We present promising experimental results showing the interest of the approach in comparison to competing methods.
